availability.licence: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.

correction.p: OCR generated transcript has not been corrected.

normalization.p: Only minor normalization where needed, if any, is indicated via markup.

punctuation.p: All punctuation marks in the source text have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.
Punctuation may be marked up with pc elements for clarification, but not exclusively.

quotation.p: All quotation marks have been retained, and are represented by appropriate Unicode code points.

hyphenation.p: Hyphenated words that appear at the end of a line have been retained. The hyphen, if present, is represented by the Unicode code point, and marked up with a pc element. The break="no" attribute on the lb element indicates that a single word is split across the lines.

interpretation.p: Dates, places, and names may be marked up, where useful.

body.ab:
DonemlS^
UAncestry
Sinsearacht DhOn na nGail
VAT Reg No: IE8214012S
Our Ref: CAM/3 574/smcc
3 October 2001
Mr Christopher A Mosher
41 Brook Pine Drive
Shelton
CT 06484-5912
USA
Dear Christopher
The initial assessment has now been carried out on your behalf and a preliminary report
of our findings is enclosed for your consideration.
I wish to apologise for the delay, which was caused by an increase in the number of
enquiries to our centre.
You will note from the preliminary report that for the most part the parish and civil
registers do not date back to the relevant period. This may be due to the conditions,
which prevailed in Ireland in the late 18"* and early 19^ centuries. The absence of
records is common, particularly in the case of members of the Catholic Church.
You will note that our researcher conducted extensive searches of the sources available
at this centre and we have uncovered records, which may be of relevance. In the
absence of parish records it is difficult to positively identify them as relevant to your
ancestors. I regret that no conclusive information has emerged from our searches.
Should you have any further queries or seek clarification on any matter, please do not
hesitate to contact me.
Kind regards.
Yours sincerely
Susan McCaffrey
Donegal Ancestry Centre
The Quay
Ramelton
Co. Donegal Ireland
Tel:+ 00 353 (0) 74 - 51266
Fax:+ 00 353 (0) 74 - 51702 E.Mail: donances@indigo.ie
Donegal Ancestry
PRELIMINARY REPORT
Name: William McLaughlin
Date of Birth: Possibly L'May 1821 or 1825
Place of Birth: Unknown, County Donegal
Denomination: Probably Catholic
We have now completed our initial assessment regarding the feasibility of carrying out
research on your family ancestors and the following is a list of the sources consulted.
Surname Variants:
The surname McLaughlin is a variant of the standard surname MacLoughlin. Other
variations include MacLaughlin, McLaughlan, McLoughlan and McLoughlin. The
surname Dougherty is a variant of the standard surname Doherty. Other variations
include Docherty, Dogherty and O'Doherty. All variations of the surnames have been
taken into consideration during this search. Until the start of the twentieth century, for
the vast majority of families in Ireland, the question of the precise spelling of their
surnames was completely irrelevant. Local accents, translation and anglicisation of
Irish names, illiteracy, poverty and lack of standard spelling all combined to produce an
enormous range of variations on what are basically the same surnames. Names
changed from generation to generation, in the same generation and even in the records
of the same individual.
Householders Index:
We commenced our investigation by consulting the Householders Index to establish
the number and location of McLaughlin properties in County Donegal
This index was compiled from Griffith's Primary Valuation (1857-1858) and the Tithe
Applotment Books (1824-1838).
McLaughlin and Doherty are two of the most commonly used surnames in County
Donegal and this is reflected in the fact that according to this index there were there
were eight hundred and twenty-eight McLaughlin and one thousand seven hundred and
seventy-five Doherty properties listed through out Donegal The distribution of these
properties by barony is as follows:
McLaughlin Inishowen East [484], Inishowen West [104], Boylagh [4],
Raphoe North [51], Raphoe South [49], Banagh [34],
Tirhugh [19] and Kilmacrenan [83].
Family Research /CAM/6
Donegal Ancestry
Doherty/Dougherty Inishowen East [828], Inishowen West [18],
Boylagh [56], Raphoe North [97], Raphoe South
[120], Banagh [90], Tirhugh [344] and
Kilmacrenan [222],
An attached explanatory sheet describes the administrative divisions used in Ireland.
These include baronies, civil parishes and townlands.
Griffith's Primary Valuation:
Arranged by groups of parishes in Poor Law Unions. This source gives the names of
owners and occupiers of both buildings and land from which the above index was
compiled.
It is possible that William McLaughlin's father James was the owner or occupier of
land at the time of this survey. We continued by conducting a search of this source
and located eighty-two entries for properties held in the name of James McLaughlin in
various locations throughout the county. It is not possible to connect any of these
records to your ancestors.
Tithe Applotment Books:
The Composition Act of 1823 specified that tithes due to the Established Church, the
Church of Ireland, which had hitherto been payable in kind, should now be paid in
money. As a result, it was necessary to carry out a valuation of the entire country,
civil parish by civil parish, to determine how much would be payable by each
landowner. This was done over the ensuing fifteen years, up to the abolition of tithes
in 1838. We hold a copy of these books for County Donegal on microfilm.
A further search of this source is not recommended as it will not be possible to be sure
of the relevance of anv records uncovered.
Passenger Lists:
We have available a list of passengers sailing from Londonderry to the US/Canada on
the J. & J. Cooke Line and the McCorkell Line from 1847 to 1871. We also hold a list
of passengers sailing from Ireland and Liverpool between 1803 and 1855.
A search of this source uncovered nineteen records in the name of William McLaughlin
from Donegal who emigrated between 1849 and 1860. In the absence of more
information regarding the place of origin of William it is not possible to be sure of the
relevance of any of these records.
Family Research /CAM/6
Donegal Ancestry
Church Records;
Before state registration of births, marriages and deaths in 1864, virtually the only
direct sources of family information are local parish registers. In general, Church of
Ireland parish registers pre-date Presbyterian and Roman Catholic records. For the
most part, how far back a family can be traced depends on the dates of the surviving
parish registers for the area.
While most Roman Catholic registers start in the latter half of the nineteenth century,
some registers in the more prosperous areas have survived from much earlier, but a
large number of these were destroyed in the PubUc Records Office fire of 1922.
Enclosed is a list of church registers for County Donegal together with a list of those
currently available at this centre. You will note that for the most part the Catholic
Church registers commence in the mid 1800's and so are too late to contain reference
to the birth/baptism of William McLaughlin or his siblings and the marriage of his
parents.
As the Established Church, the Church of Ireland, claimed the right to administer
baptism, marriages and burial ceremonies and in the eighteenth and early nineteenth
centuries especially, due to prevailing laws, the records of births, marriages and deaths
of other denominations are often found in the registers of the Church of Ireland
A full search of all records currently available on our database failed to locate any
reference to William McLaughlin, his siblings or his parents.
Gravestone Inscriptions:
We hold a number of gravestone inscriptions from various graveyards around the
County. A search of this uncovered several McLaughlin entries however it is not
possible to be sure of the relevance of any of these records.
Civil Records:
State registration of all births, marriages and deaths began in Ireland in 1864; non-
Roman Catholic marriages are registered from 1845.
County Donegal is divided into 52 civil parishes and by nine Poor Law Unions, namely
Ballyshannon, Donegal, Glenties, Stranorlar, Dunfanaghy, Letterkenny, IVfilford, Deny
and Inishowen. Each of these Unions is further divided into Dispensary Districts.
There are forty registration districts in the county.
It is possible that the parents of William McLaughlin died after 1864 but again without
knowing where in Donegal your ancestor resided it is not possible to carry out a search
of the civil death registers.
Family Research /CAM/6
Donegal Ancestry
Census Records:
The earliest surviving Census return for County Donegal is the 1901 Census. This lists
all those present in the household on the night of the Census (31st March 1901), their
relationship to the householder, religion, occupation, age and other details.
The 1911 Census is now available on microfilm.
In the absence of more information regarding the place of origin of
William McLaughlin it would not be possible to make any connection between your
ancestor and the numerous McLaughlin families in these sources.
Family Research /CAM/6

Baronies and Civil parishes of Donegal.
Administrative Divisions
Civil parish
This is the most widely used land division. The civil parish, in use since the I?"'
centur}', was based on monastic and church settlements and used extensively in
surveys. This division generally coincides with the Church of Ireland parishes. There
are fifty-two civil parishes in County Donegal. (See attached Map).
Records compiled by civil parish include: Hearth Money Rolls, 19''' century Census
Records, Tithe Books, Griffith's Valuation.
Bni'onv
Civil parishes are collected together to form baronies. This term originated in Celtic
Ireland from the tribal land divisions of the tiiatha. This is now an obsolete division,
but in the 19''' century it wms widely used. There are eight baronies in Donegal -
Inishowen East and West, Kilmacrennan, Boylagh, Banagh, Tirhugh and Raphoe
North and South. Records organised by barony include the 17''' centuiy surveys, early
19''' century Tithe Books and mid 19'" century Griftlth's Valuation.
Records organised by barony include: 17'" century sur\-eys, 19"' centuiy Tithe Books,
Griffith's Valuation.
Poor Law Union
Under the Poor Relief Act, 1838, Ireland was divided into districts or Unions in \vhich
the local rateable inhabitants were to be financially responsible for the care of all
paupers in their areas. By 1850, 163 workhouses were built throughout the country.
7'hese workhouses were usually situated in a large market town and served
surrounding parishes and townlands, in many cases they ignored existing boundaries
of parishes and counties. Land divisions within Poor Law Unions were divided into
Dispensary Districts in which a dispensary and a doctor was located. After civil
registration began in 1864 these Dispensary Districts also became Registrars Districts.
The Registrar was responsible for collecting all the registrations of births, marriages
and deaths within each District.
Records organised by Poor Law Union include: Indexes to civil births, marriages and
deaths, GiilTitli's Valuation,
Town land
The townland is the smallest and most ancient administrative division of land. It
usually referred to a landmark strongly associated with a locality, ie, a mountain, a
bog, a village, a church or a fort. It is usually what most researchers try to identify
when carrying out genealogical research. Townlands are grouped together to form
civil parishes. The number of townlands within a parish may differ greatly from one
parish to another.

NOTE
The National Archives has customs passenger lists dating back to 1820 with a few as early as 1787, Lists prior to 1820 that are not at
the National Archives may be on file at the port of entry or the State archives In the State where the port is located. The Morton Allan
Directory of European Passenger Steamship Arrivals may be useful in determining the name and arrival date of ships arriving at New
York, 1890—1930, and Philadelphia, Baltimore, and Boston, 1904—1926.
Please fill In as much of the information called for above as possible. We will advise you if the information is inadequate to enable us to
locate the entry you are seeking.
We do not maintain a list of persons who do research for a fee; however, many researchers advertise their services in genealogical
periodicals, usually available in libraries.

DATE SEARCHEDROLL
□ A SEARCH WAS NOT MADE FOR THE REASON INDICATED:
1. Our index to New York passenger arrivals covers the periods 1820 — 1846 and 1897 —
1943. We regret that we cannot undertake a page-by-page search of the lists for the
period between 1847 — 1896, inclusive.
2. Masters of vessels departing from U.S. ports were not required to list the names of
passengers. Therefore, we would not have a list for the passenger you have cited.
3. Our holdings of passenger lists do not include any for Pacific coast ports. The San
Francisco passenger lists were destroyed by fires in 1851 and 1940. (Consult the two
works by Louis J. Pasmussen, San Francisco Ship Passenger Lists, 4 vols., 1965; and
Railway Passenger Lists of Overland Trains to San Francisco and the West, 1 vol., 1966.)
4. Overland arrivals into the U.S. from Canada and Mexico are notdocumented in passenger
list records.
5. Justice Department restrictions prohibit us from making searches in Immigration and
Naturalization records less than 50 years old. We suggest that you direct an inquiry to:
District Director, Immigration and Naturalization Service, New York, NY 10007.
NATIONAL ARCHIVES TRUST FUND BOARD NATF FORM 40 (12-79)
j tec'rei !« -sH
y .iA:}! '•
PASSENGER LISTS IN THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
1. We found several entries for persons of the same name arriving at the same port during the same period. Additional . '
information, such as age, occupation„etc., will help in resolving this problem.
:.w;
2. We found the requested information on the passenger index, but we regret that the corresponding passenger list
is missing. A copy of the index card is enclosed. , i
3. We are unable to locate the passenger list for the ship listed and have found no entry on the passenger index for the
requested party at that port. hJ-
□
n
4. We examined the passenger list for the requested-shipand were unable to find an entry Tor the-requested passenger,—
5. The register of ship arrivals did not show any entry for the ship named. ' • -
6. Our only passenger lists for the cited port do not cover the date that you have requested, and we were unable to
find an entry on the index to the l ists we have. £-4 ^
7. You may find some help in the book Irish and Scotch-Irish Ancestral Research by Margaret Dickson Falley (1962).
It is a guide to genealogical records and repositories in Ireland and is normally available in larger libraries.
8. Passports are issued to persons leaving the U.S., not arriving but early arrivals are frequently documented in passen
ger lists, which are described in the enclosed leaflet.
9. The National Archives has abstracts of Naturalization proceedings for the New England States (1787 — 1906) and
the District of Columbia (1802 — 1926). For information about citizenship granted elsewhere before September
27, 1906, send inquiries to the clerk of the Federal, State, or other court that issued the naturalization certificate.
The Immigration and Natural ization Service, Washington, DC 20536, can furnish information on natural izations
that occurred after September 26, 1906.
10. It should be noted that the passenger l ists in our custody do not represent a complete collection. Some passenger
lists of the 19th century were either lost or destroyed by dampness, fire, and other causes before records of this
type were deposited in the National Archives.
